text: We are in a fusty grandmother’s apartment. Faded rugs, et smells. Old world Egyptian food on the stove and near rea MRS. FADIL is 68, squat and exacting. And right now stand on the creaky, teetering stool... reaching way up a top s to get a JAR of preserved lemons. We fear for an awful fa The cat HISSES. The stool RIGHTS. She gets what she needs just fine and steps down. She chides the cat, accent thic
Mind your own. The cat keeps fixed on the stool. She returns to the stew simmering on the stove. Slices and stirs. Tastes.
Perfect. Too good for them, eight grandchildren, each smart as a table. Assaf with his music... Sounds like you. The cat mews again tunelessly.

No, it’s too early to fry the onions. Assaf likes them crisp. (tastes again, frowns) Not perfect. More cinnamon. She steps to the CREAKY stool -- about to teeter when -- KNOCK at the door stops her from climbing again.

Assaf? I tell you no come before 5! And no bring me more laundry! I tell you I am done being your maid -- She opens the door, surprised to find not her grandson b a large, severe, gorgeous DARK MAN. He speaks as one accustomed to having his words carved in stone. And if in eyes you should see your ancestors waving do not be surpr This is ANUBIS.
You are in wrong floor. The black people family is upstairs.
No mistake. You are to come with me. Mrs. Fadil. You have died, Mrs. Fadil. And it is time for you to come with me. A beat as she studies him. First skeptical. Then annoyed.

I not going anywhere. I have company soon, if you are here to rob then rob and go. There is a television and I have a phone my grandson says is also a camera. Anubis steps in, weary. Used to this. Firm and sympatheti

I wish I was but a thief. I amnot. I am of Death. You are dead, Mrs. Fadil. He points. On the kitchen floor -- by the overturned stoo IS HER BODY. Unmoving. Left eye blood-specked. Neck bent an impossible angle. Death has little dignity.
That is me.

That is you. (goes distant) Your family will come soon and find you. They will do right by your body and bury you as is proper. They will be sad for a time and then they will find happiness again. Your Assaf will marry in a year and name is first daughter for you. Mrs. Fadil takes her time taking this in.
A bullshit middle name? He smiles. It is beautiful.
A bullshit middle name. Not much choice, she accepts this. Leans to inspect her b
This is how they will find me? She adjusts her skirt. Straightens a leg. Suddenly -- she turns on him. Studies him.
This is a Muslim home. Why does Anubis hold out his hand for me?
It is my thanks. He stares out. His eyes go shimmery, reflective and in th we catch glimpses of the IMAGES he describes.

You were once a girl with your own Tita. Who taught you the ways of Egypt old, of when the Nile was full and flooding. She told you the stories... Of the Wolf and the Jackal... The Red Wind and the Nine Broken Seals... Of the Child of Bast...
I remember.
You do. He opens a closet. Secreted away, wrapped in satin, is a but well-kept STUFFED CATSKIN on a pole. AN ANUBIS FETISH

You kept this for me. Now you are the Tita and you have taught your Assaf to keep it when you fall. For that -- I bring you to the Scales. Come. She does not come. But lowers the heat on the stove toa simmer. Puts a spoon in her stew, holds it out for him.
My family will find me, they will not try it. You taste. Beat. Anubis takes the smallest sip. Enough to mean it:
It is perfect.
(she knows it) 68 years. Not much for America, but more than my Tita ever prayed for.

Come. He is of a sudden by the fire escape. Hand outstretched. is not a question. Mrs. Fadil swallows and... EXT. FIRE ESCAPE. MRS. FADIL’S BUILDING. EVENING. ...She climbs behind Anubis. Nimble and dauntless. One flight... Another... They climb... And climb... And goddammit if the cat doesn’t follow leaping behind th Another flight. They should have reached the roof by now.

How many stairs? She looks up at Anubis. He peers back down at her. His he briefly that of A JACKAL. WIDE ON THE BUILDING. The wall goes up for MILES. No end sight. Mrs. Fadil and Anubis tiny against it. With each floor they climb reality and physics become less consiste important. The world less like the world... Until finally CLOSE ON: THE TOP OF A LADDER. Anubis climbs off. Mrs. Fadil after. She looks up, eyes instantly filled with won
This is not Queens.

This is not Queens. EXT. DESERT OASIS. EVENING. Tawny sand under a burnished sunset. Date palms slow danc with the khamsin. Pyramids in the distance. Stars above. Anubis offers Mrs. Fadil a seat on a BLANKET. The cat lea onto her lap. He offers dates and tea from a tray. She declines. He removes the tray, REVEALING: A SET OF SCALES
You are comfortable. Meh. Anubis produces A LONG FEATHER. Reaches out...  HIS HAND DISAPPEARS INTO HER CHEST. WITHDRAWS HOLDING... HER HEART. It beats two final times. Goes still in his ha
I was using that -- !
We shall see if you used it well.

I -- was unkind to the first boy who loved me. I stole a doll once from my cousin. I tried my best. Each takes their place on the scale. Heart weighed agains feather. The scales dip first one way... then the other.. As they teeter... the sky changes, sunset to darkest midn Stars rotating, shifting, constellations forming, reformi back to ancient configurations, the sky at Egypt’s dawn.. Until the scales finally settle. AT EVEN.
Your best is good. Mrs. Fadil puffs her chest. Anubis gestures. Before them -- perhaps always -- are several DOORS set in the sand.
Each will take you to the Du’at. The Du’at has many worlds. Choose.
Which has my father? He beat me and I would like not to see his world.
Choose.

You are a kind boy. You choose for me. Anubis accepts the charge with solemnity. Considers the options. Selects and opens A DOOR. We do not see inside, though much watery light glimmers from within. Mrs. Fadil walks to it. Eyes clear and young reflecting the light. But she hesitates at the door. At the end suddenly scared

You’re sure I do this with you? Follow the wrong god and I do not see my Tita again. He gestures -- AND THE CAT LEAPS AT MRS. FADIL. PUSHING THROUGH THE DOOR. INTO THE LIGHT. THE DOOR SLAMS. ON ANUBIS. Framed by a shifting sky. The moon sets. The cat lands on the sand. Licks herself absently. And we BEGIN PULL BACK... OVER THE DESERT... EXT. DESERT. DAY. CAMERA GLIDES OVER SAND and ROCK as the FANTASTICAL DESER ANCIENT EGYPT slowly becomes more and more banal and FANT gives way to the ugly REALITY of MIDDLE AMERICA flatlands A VOICE COMES, raspy and rich with the gravel of hindsigh
Best thing, only good thing, about being in prison is the relief... EXT. PRISON. DAY. GLIDING OVER a grey cinder block made of grey cinder bloc

You don’t worry if they're gonna get you when they already got you. Tomorrow can't do anything today hasn't already Managed. EXT. PRISON YARD. DAY. DOZENS OF PRISONER work out in the exterior gym. CAMERA F “LOW KEY” LYESMITH, a wiry man with a scarred smile and m minute mouth. He is, as usual, mid theory: “LOW KEY” LYESMITH ...Even better with a death sentence. Bang. The worst has happened. You get a few days for it to sink in, then you’re riding the cart on your way to do the dance on nothing. A ROW OF WEIGHTS are repeatedly pumped into FRAME in a be press emanating from JUST BELOW FRAME. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH This country went to hell when they stopped hanging folks. No gallows dirt. No gallows deals.
A lithe, powerful frame that makes some assume his mind i as keen as it is or his words as carefully chosen. Hard t pin for age or ethnicity but if you had to guess you’d sa and black.

(pushing) No gallows humor. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH Funniest fucking shit in the world. A GROUP OF WHITE SUPREMACISTS exercise in a gaggle and ac from them, eyes locked on Shadow. “Low Key” continues tal M.O.S. as Shadow sits up after the last strained press. CAMERA PUSHES IN as Shadow looks up to the sky.

I'm not superstitious. And I believe in plenty. When there is reason and evidence to believe. I don't believe in anything I can’t see. SHADOW’S PO.V. -- THE SKY. Beyond the pumping bar that ri and falls, away and toward CAMERA, STORM CLOUDS start to
But in the last days of my three years of incarceration, I feel disaster hovering above me. Shadow takes a deep breath.
I can't see it. But I believe it.
I smell snow. He glances across the yard and sees the WHITE SUPREMACIST staring at him as they dangle the jump rope noose.
Shadow stares back at the White Supremacists.
Shadow leans against his prison cell door, looking out at other PRISONERS in the common area below. The COIN is rol along the knuckles of Shadow’s hand.

I keep looking for signs of the bad thing that's going to happen. A SUDDEN, VIOLENT BRAWL ERUPTS in the cell next to theirs Shadow watches as two MASSIVE PRISONERS crash into the bannister outside the cells, one of them TUMBLING OVER an falling to the floor below, violently breaking his neck. “Low Key” Lyesmith lays on his bed reading a battered paperback copy of Herotodus’s Histories. There’s a STACK books on the floor. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH It is the age of outrage. Everyone is aggrieved about something. GUARDS descend on the remaining Massive Prisoner, who cla
It wasn’t me! Shadow watches the Massive Prisoner dragged into his cell

Nothing’s ever anybody’s fault. They say you did when you didn’t. Or you didn’t do quite like they said you did. Everybody's wearing false dignity pants. And they lie. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH I lie all the time. It should be expected. More narrative freedom when you lie. I’m surprised when people tell the truth, honestly.

I am a seeker of truth who has not yet arrived at conviction. Shadow flips the coin. Catches it. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH You're as easy to read as that coin. Tails. Shadow shows him. It’s HEADS. And -- CLOSE ON: A NORTH AMERICAN SONGBIRD PERCHED ON A BRANCH.  INT. PRISON WOOD SHOP. DAY. THE BIRD is the model for the month of SEPTEMBER in the SONGBIRDS OF NORTH AMERICA CALENDAR. Five unchecked boxes before a circled date: September 19.

Five boxes to cross below a White-Cheeked Bulbuls then I'll be home. INMATES work at tables assembling DOZENS OF ELABORATE BIR FEEDERS. “Low Key” slots in the sides of a bird feeder, passes it to Shadow who bolts and screws it tight. Too ti A piece CRACKS off. “Low Key” grabs the glue to fix it. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH Calm the fuck down. You’re making me nervous.

I got a feeling deep in my stomach something is entirely wrong. The last week was worse than the whole three years put together. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH That hollow in the pit of your stomach is just you afraid of going back to the real world. You’ve honed survival skills in here -- be careful in their application outside. Take a lesson from Johnnie Larch.

I don’t know Joh-- “LOW KEY” LYESMITH Johnnie Larch got out after five years. Gets to the airport. Hands his ticket to the woman at the counter, who asks for his driver's license. He gives it to her. She says, “It’s expired.” He says, “It might not be valid as a drivers license but it is a damn fine identification. There’s my picture, my height, and my weight. Who the fuck do you think it is?” She says “I’1l thank you not to use that kind of language, ‘sir.'" He says, “Give me my fucking boarding pass right fucking now.” “Low Key” takes the slotted sides of the bird feeder and them to a base.  lu. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH (CONT’D) Now he was right to take that tone. She was disrespecting him. He’s not going to be disrespected. You don’t let people disrespect you in prison, why the fuck would he let her disrespect him as a free man? She pushes a button. Security shows up. He’s back in prison. Do you understand what I’m saying here?

One of those ‘behaviors that work in a specialized environment, such as a prison, can often fail to work, and in fact become harmful, when used outside such an environment’ sort of situations. “LOW KEY” LYESMITH No, dummy. I’m saying: “Do not piss off those bitches in airports.” (off Shadow’s look) Listen to me. This is sacred knowledge I am passing down. Do not. Piss off. Those bitches. In airports. When you’re out in the world getting your first blow job as a free man, remember this face, because you will have me to thank. He gives a big shit eating grin, and -- INT. PRISON. PHONE BANK. NIGHT.

PULL BACK TO REVEAL A ROW OF TELEPHONES as if they were dancers in a Busby Berkeley. CAMERA CONTINUES PULLING BAC past an 70 year old black man named SAM FETISHER (speakin hushed tones to his own phone) TO REVEAL... SHADOW leanin against the wall, curled against a phone:
Something feels weird.
That wasn't the first thing I said to her. First thing I said was:
I love you. (then) Something feels weird.
I love you, too. What feels weird?
I don’t know. The weather. Air feels constipated like if it’d just push out a storm, it’d be okay.
There’s a special word for the kind of dread caused by constipated air. (then) It’s nice here. Leaves haven't all fallen. If we don’t get a storm, you'll see them when you get home.
Five days.
A hundred and twenty hours and you’re home. Sam Fetisher finishes his call, hangs up. As he passes:
Storm’s on the way.
Maybe it’11 snow. Sam stops, glancing back at Shadow.
Not that kind of storm. Bigger storms than that coming. Better off in here than out on the street when the big storm comes.
I’m on the phone.
Keep your head down, boy. It’s like -- what do they call those things continents ride around on?
Tectonic plates.
Tectonic plates.
Tectonic plates. When they go riding, when North America goes skidding into South America, you don’t want to be in the middle.  12. Shadow watches Sam go, a stab of dread, back to the phone
Everything's okay there, right?
Waiting for the sky to fall is gonna cause more bother than the sky actually falling, which it isn’t.
Nothing’s wrong?
Everything's fine. Robbie’s coming by. We’re planning your surprise party. Welcome home.
A surprise party?
Which you know nothing about.
Not a thing.
I love you, puppy.

I love you, too. Shadow hangs up the phone and dread mounts and -- INT. PRISON LIBRARY. DAY. THE GROUP OF SKINHEADS pile on Shadow, POUNDING HIM. Tryi to bait him into a fight. To get him to hit back.

Prison has a way of trying to keep you in prison. They’1l do anything to keep you inside. With them. ON SHADOW. Severe as he takes the hits. Doesn’t fight bac INT. PRISON CELL. NIGHT. PAN OVER Low Key in the top bunk, sleeping without troubl over to... THE WINDOW. A WILD STORM rages outside. CAMERA FLOATS DOWN TO... SHADOW. Bruised. Sleep fighting him. He stares at the cinder block ceiling.  is.

I love you, too. BACK ON SHADOW. He rolls over. Finally able to rest.
That was the first time I dreamt the Bone Orchard. The Tree. EXT. THE BONE ORCHARD. NIGHT. SHADOW’S P.O.V. -- MOVING THROUGH A CEMETARY UNDER MOONLI
I’m no stranger to nightmare. This was new. This was angry. This was old.

text: The TREES increase in size as he moves deeper into the Orchard. Roots going deep down into the graves. Branches ending in bony HANDS. GRASPING at him as he walks. A HAND CUTS his cheek. Retracts with the BLOOD. All the other HANDS retreat, crowding it like a sacred prize. Clearing a swath for Shadow to see...

head_text.subj: THE GREAT BONY TREE IN THE CENTER

text: A massive, leafless ASH. Its branches end in grasping, ha flesh hands. The fingers of one who died trying to claw t coffin lid. All the other trees bow to it. Large, strange fruit swings from its branches like drupes Size and shape of HEADLESS MEN. The Tree’s bony hand/bran reach out to Shadow... drawing him closer... Something swings down. HITS him in the face.
Shadow SHOCKS AWAKE in his bed.  14.
48 hours left to daylight... INT. PRISON FOOD HALL. DAY. Shadow over oatmeal and prison coffee, doesn’t touch eith Revelation hitting with migraine force. He can feel it:
...And then -- I taste metal in my mouth. Tin foil in the teeth. Burnt hair. (beat ) Whatever it is... now was. Something happened. GUARD calls out to the hall:
Shadow Moon. All eyes land on Shadow. Shadow sits up. Breath held. Fea

This way. INT. HALLWAY. PRISON. SHADOW’S P.O.V. -- FOLLOWING GUARD down the long hall. Hi walk reminiscent of his walk through the Bone Orchard. Guard gives him a look. Sees the bruises on his face. They pass the group of SKINHEADS. One mimes a HANGING. INT. OUTSIDE WARDEN’S OFFICE. Guard presses a button under a MINIATURE TRAFFIC LIGHT at Warden’s door. He waits in silence. The TRAFFIC LIGHT BUZZES. Turns GREEN. INT. WARDEN’S OFFICE. The WARDEN wears an old suit he’1ll wear for another deca His fidgets with a hearing aid, not new either. Shadow’s heart races audibly.
By the time I get there I’m ready for anything. Except polite. Warden is waiting for Shadow. Has a chair set out for him
Thank you for coming. Sit down. Please.  Lo. Shadow sits. Worries even more.
Nothing good comes after polite.
Says here you were sentenced to six years for aggravated assault and battery.
Yes, Sir.

You served three -- and were due to be released on Friday. (off his look) Shadow, we’re going to be releasing you later this afternoon. You'll be getting out a couple of days early. (beat) There’s no good way to say this so I’1l put it plain. This came from Johnson Memorial Hospital in Eagle Point... Your wife. She died in the early hours of this morning. It was an automobile accident. I’m sorry. He slides a piece of paper across his desk for Shadow to Shadow doesn’t. Doesn’t say a word.

head_text.subj: A_RINGING BUILDS... PAINFUL... LIKE A BOMB WENT OFF TOO

text: CLOSE AND WON’T STOP EXPLODING OUR EARS... INT. PRISON HALLWAY. DAY. The Guard walks Shadow back to his cell.

It’s like one of them good-news, bad-news jokes, isn’t it? Good news, we’re letting you out early, bad news, your wife is dead. He LAUGHS. The cell door SLAMS shut on Shadow. INT. PRISON CELL. DAY. A RAZOR scrapes over Shadow’s neck... A BUTTON stretches to contain his chest... A plain clothes Shadow steps out of his cell... The door SLAMS behind him. We hear nothing but the RING.  Lo. EXT. PRISON. DAY. Shadow emerges from prison into gray sky and freezing rai Ice pellets sting his face as he follows the dotted line INT. YELLOW SCHOOL BUS. DAY. The OTHER RELEASED INMATES whoop and cheer. Shadow stares the window, hears none of it. EXT. BUS STATION. DAY. Shadow slides into a cab, not bothering to shake off the INT. AIRPORT TICKET COUNTER. DAY. THE RINGING STOPS. Shadow’s tries, patient and polite. Bu the AIRPORT LADY is congenitally unkind.
I’m sorry, it’s our policy, I can’t change a ticket for two days from now for today. If you change your departure date from Friday you have to pay the difference and a $200 change fee.
Plus the difference in fare. Do you have to fly today?
I need to get to Eagle Point. It’s -- for a funeral.

(heard it all before) Not without an original death certificate. No emails, no copies. A neck-snapping rage builds in Shadow. He GRIPS the desk. Then catches the briefest GLIMPSE of LOW KEY in the crowd Gone in an blink, not really there, but enough to remind
“Sacred knowledge. Do not piss off those bitches in airports.”

How much is the flight tomorrow?  INT. AIRPORT TERMINAL. NIGHT. A SERIES OF DISSOLVES, AS: Shadow tries to sleep in an airport chair. Sitting up... Stretched across... Legs up for the floor waxer... Sleep fails. INT. AIRPORT KIOSK. THE NEXT MORNING.
Shadow, unslept, suit rumpled, pulls together a breakfast whatever’s not candy. The register asks for $18.50.

That’s a four dollar apple. I went to jail for stealing. CASHIER shrugs, moves off to help another CUSTOMER. At wh Shadow notices she just left A $20 BILL ON THE COUNTER. H quickly palms the 20. Vanished in his hand. Cashier comes back, smiling. No clue. Beat. Shadow “notices” the 20 on the floor. Hands it back.
You dropped this. He opens up his wallet to pay honestly and... INT. GATE. AIRPORT. DAY. Shadow is at a electronics kiosk, a new CELL PHONE unwrap He dials. A VOICE MAIL picks up.

Hey, Robbie. They tell me Laura’s dead. They let me out early. I’m coming home. He hangs up. A beat. A thought. He dials another number. Another VOICE MAIL picks up: LAURA’S VOICE MAIL MESSAGE Hi, you’ve reached Laura -- or I guess you didn’t. I probably won’t hear this, I never check these. But hey, do what you want. BEEP. Shadow hangs up. It good to hear her voice, it’s horrible to hear her voice. His attention shifts hearing A fuss going on at THE COUNTER. A stooped OLD MAN mumble- SHOUTS at the same Airport Lady Shadow dealt with yesterd Growing increasingly agitated. People notice.  15.
I bought it -- I did I did! -- I have to get to my son -- his christening. Bought a First Class ticket --
This isn’t a First Class --

I sent the check! Look here’s my name -- I need to get back, he was just born two days ago. We named him... named him... The Old Man trails off. Can’t remember. Alzheimer confusi Making an uncomfortable, cringing scene.
Are you sure you’re supposed to be flying alone, Sir.

No no no! Alone? My son’s supposed to fly with me -- he takes care of everything, the bills -- I just have to get to his christening and everything’11 be fine. He’1ll take care of... He SOBS. Everyone is horrified...

Every sport has its pros. Watching the best reminds you why you quit. Better to be a fan in the stands and cheer. ...Everyone except Shadow. He smiles. Watches Airport Lad crumble, turning to a FLIGHT ATTENDANT.
Just get him on and stick him in First. She hands the Old Man a new ticket, and... INT. PLANE. DAY. CLOSE ON: A TICKET. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT reads it dumbly.
Okay, but can you take your seat?
This lady is sitting in it. 17-D times two. Perhaps you now see the problem. Shadow stands in the aisle over a WOMAN already seated. T plane is FULL. RAIN smacks the windows.  iy.
I’1l need you to take another seat.
Just point to one and I’1l1 take it. INT. FIRST CLASS. PLANE. MOMENTS LATER.
Attendant offers Shadow a First Class chair.
Really?

You want it or not? Fuck yeah. Shadow sits. Looks around the roomy cabin. A FIRST CLASS FLIGHT ATTENDANT brings a cup of nuts to the passenger beside him: The OLD MAN from the gate. Only now, sitting in first class, drink in hand, he seems younger. Whatever was decrepit about him shucked off to reveal a vibrant, chummy, chatty man of, say, 60 undernea A glimmer and gut evinces a love of food and sex and sand his toes, though better all three while drunk. As charism as they come. Just try not to stare at the glass eye. Meet MISTER WEDNESDAY.
Guess this is your lucky day. Cashews. Love ‘em. Native of Brazil but grow like motherfuckers in Florida. He crunches a handful. A lovely FLIGHT ATTENDANT COMES.
I’m supposed to take your glass, Sir

But you’re not going to, otherwise you would have said I need to take your drink or I’m gonna take your drink, neither of which happened. Don’t worry, I’11 hold her tight. (off Shadow) Give my friend here a Jack and Coke while you pour me another, please.
Shadow stiffens as the plane begins to takes off.
Nervous?  ZU.
Never flown before.
Nothing to it. Just sit in a chair and be a bird. Drink up -- He hands Shadow his drink to finish off. Shadow hesitates
I give you the worm from my beak and you look at me like I fucked your mom.
Sorry. You’re just the first person I’ve talked to who wasn’t an asshole.
Gimme time. Shadow drinks. Savors it. God, that’s good.
Nice work on the upgrade. Straight up sympathy play. Risky. An eyebrow cocks. Someone who speaks the language.

Airlines are the ultimate Clip Joint. Promise of sex in exotic locals, lucky if you get a bag of pretzels. They deserve that and worse. What might you have tried, my boy? Shadow decides in this moment to like this guy, and so to a lot of inane shit slide. Beat.
The Good Samaritan. Maybe Gentleman’s Curve. If I was a traveling man.
Which you are not?
No, Sir, not me.
Sounds like a firm decision made for good reasons. I can respect that. A man gets out of prison, he should be focused above all on not going back. How the fuck did you know that?

Don’t mind me. Got an eye for these things. Just the one. (studies Shadow) You’re new to the fresh air, I can see that much. Not seeing the joy though the first steak and lay halo they all got. You look the sort who’s lost something vital, and not just time... He lets that sit. For a moment Shadow even considers tell
So what should I call you if I was inclined to do so?
Shadow Moon.
That, my boy, is one outstandingly improbable name. Shadow Moon. Moonshadow. Goddamn hippy parents.
Hippy parent.
Momma had a giant afro I bet. Dancing queen.
The whole kit. And if I was inclined, what should I call you?
What’s today?
Wednesday.
Today’s my day. Let’s go with that. Their drinks come, Mister Wednesday hands Shadow his. Che Shadow tries not to spill as the plane RATTLES. Turbulenc picks up with the now whipping RAIN.
Always good to meet a fellow traveller Shadow.
I’m not --  ZZ.
-- Of course. My mistake. When you were then, what was your speciality.
Banks.
Bang bang. Big time.
And some small time. Shadow takes out a dime, performs a smooth Spellbound. Poof... It a quarter.
Better at the small than big.

You got more gifts than me. I’ve got two. Number one, I can sleep anywhere, anytime. Number two is I tend to get what I want. On average, over time. It’s all about making people believe in you. Not their cash, their faith. Hell, look at this plane. By all rights this 80 ton chub of metal and seat cushion and Bloody Mary mix has no business soaring through the sky...
As if to punctuate his point LIGHTNING FIRES outside the window. The plane quakes. Mister Wednesday never flinches

Then along came Newton to explain air flow over the wing creating lift or some shit... and though it makes not a lick of sense here are 282 passengers believing it so hard the plane continues on its journey safely. Is it their faith that keeps us aloft? Or is it Newton? They give you a free shit kit in first class. Little toothbrush, little socks. You might not have known that.

LIGHTNING AGAIN. CLOSER now. Passengers grow nervous. Shadow kills his drink. The CAPTAIN warbles some nonsense the PA that Wednesday ignores, busy putting on the little socks from his free shit kit and signaling the Attendant.
Another couple’a Jack and Cokes, my dear. (to Shadow) How’re you fixed for work?  255
Who needs work when you’re rich?

As it happens I’m in a hiring position. I could be Mister Wednesday with a shake of a hand. All perfectly legal work more or less, good money, open roads, bit of risk by and by, then again I’m one of the few who’d without hesitation hire an ex- con. Don’t rush into it, take your time.
No, thank you. Already have a job at my buddy’s gym waiting for me.

No you don’t. I could use a fellow like you. There’s always work for a big guy who’s smart enough to know he’s better off letting folks think he’s dumb. Did I mention the bonuses? Remarkable benefits. I’11 throw in a pension if you’d like and can explain what the fuck a pension is. Hell by the end of your tenure you could be the next king of America.
I told you, I have a job --

-- I can see your reluctance, my boy, all’s fair there. A wise man once said, “A man gets out of prison, he should be focused above all on not going back.” Again, don’t rush into it. He winks his good eye. Shadow is uncomfortable with everything about his offer. Finishes his drink. Finishes Wednesday’s for good measure.
Been a rough day. He tilts his chair back all the way. Closes his eyes to s out Wednesday and the world. Tries to sleep.

INSERT CUT: LAURA’S FACE. A RICTUS OF HORROR AS HEADLIGHT COME CRASHING INTO HER. Shadow starts. Puts on the sleep mask from his kit.  24. I want to go to my wife’s funeral. I want to say goodbye. After that, if you still need me, I will start at two thousand dollars a week.
